Saraceni</name>    <email>saraceni@verizon.net</email>   </author>   <summary type="html"><div class="feed-description"><p>VARNA, BULGARIA\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd<a href="http://archaeologyinbulgaria.com/2015/03/17/archaeologists-dig-up-ancient-skeleton-under-odessos-fortress-wall-in-bulgarias-varna/" target="_blank"><em>Archaeology in Bulgaria</em></a> reports that the skeleton of a tall man was unearthed during rescue excavations near the St. Nikolay Church in Varna by archaeologists from the Varna Museum of Archaeology. Part of the skeleton, dated to the late fourth century or early fifth century A.D., is located beneath the fortress wall of the ancient city of Odessos. The man may have died in an accident during the construction of the ancient wall, and his remains laid in the deep pit, which was dug as a construction ditch for the foundation of the wall. \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdIt is possible that someone used the pit, which had been dug up [for construction purposes], to bury the body,\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd said lead archaeologist Valeri Yotov.&nbsp;</p></div></summary>   <content type="html"><div class="feed-description"><p>VARNA, BULGARIA\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd<a href="http://archaeologyinbulgaria.com/2015/03/17/archaeologists-dig-up-ancient-skeleton-under-odessos-fortress-wall-in-bulgarias-varna/" target="_blank"><em>Archaeology in Bulgaria</em></a> reports that the skeleton of a tall man was unearthed during rescue excavations near the St. Nikolay Church in Varna by archaeologists from the Varna Museum of Archaeology. An expert commission recommended preserving and exhibiting the site in situ. Saraceni</name>    <email>saraceni@verizon.net</email>   </author>   <summary type="html"><div class="feed-description"><p><img class="caption" style="margin-right: 15px; float: left;" title="(Maloff1)" src="images/News/1503/Leluh-Ruins-Kosrae-Micronesia.jpg" alt="" width="320" height="213" />PERTH, AUSTRALIA\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdThe royal tombs in the ancient city of Leluh, located just off the mainland of Kosrae, a Micronesian island, may be older than had been previously thought. The city was home to high chiefs and others from about 1250 until the mid-nineteenth century, when whalers, traders, and missionaries started to arrive on the island. Leluh features canals and walled compounds built of basalt, and temporary, pyramid-shaped tombs, or <em>saru</em>, built from living coral. Historical sources indicate that when Kosraean high chiefs died, their bodies were rubbed with coconut oil and then wrapped in mats and cords to be buried in the <em>saru</em> for up to three months. The bones were later exhumed, cleaned, and reburied in a hole on the nearby reef. \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdToday, the ancient tombs of the royal burial complexes are one of the few parts of the ancient Leluh site that remain intact. Much of the historical site is overgrown by the tropical forest and has succumbed to hundreds of years of tropical weather and tidal inundation, and some parts of the site have been dismantled and reused in modern construction,\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Zoe Richards of the Western Australian Museum told <a href="http://www.livescience.com/50135-coral-tombs-leluh-700-years-old.html" target="_blank"><em>Live Science</em></a>. Uranium-thorium dating of the coral in the tombs shows that they could have been built as early as the fourteenth century, or about 300 years earlier than previously thought. \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdTo extract and translocate the amount of coral used to build the <em>saru</em>, as well as the structures and walls throughout Leluh, would have required a highly structured social order that could organize and demand significant labor and logistical support from the population,\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd she added. Saraceni</name>    <email>saraceni@verizon.net</email>   </author>   <summary type="html"><div class="feed-description"><p><img class="caption" style="margin-right: 15px; float: left;" title="(Rishi Aryal)" src="images/News/1503/Maya-papaya-domestication.JPG" alt="" width="298" height="269" />CHAMPAIGN, ILLINOIS\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdA genetic study of the sex chromosomes of the papaya plant suggests that the hermaphrodite version of the plant, which produces the fruit desired by growers, was first cultivated some 4,000 years ago by the Maya. Today, growing hermaphrodite papaya plants in costly and inefficient because farmers cannot tell which seeds are hermaphrodites until the plant has flowered. Ray Ming of the <a href="http://news.illinois.edu/news/15/0317Papaya_RayMing.html" target="_blank">University of Illinois</a>, interested in understanding the plant\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds reproduction in order to produce a \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdtrue-breeding\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd hermaphrodite papaya, tracked down the mutation that caused male plants to alter to the hermaphrodite form. He and his team found less than half of one percent difference between the male and hermaphrodite sequences, indicating that the change happened relatively recently. \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdOur analyses date the divergence (of male and hermaphrodite papaya) to around 4,000 years (ago), well after the domestication of crop plants in Mesoamerica more than 6,200 years ago, and coinciding with the rise of Maya civilization about 4,000 years ago,\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd the team wrote in the journal <em>Genome Research</em>. And since wild hermaphrodite papayas have not been found in Central America, \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdThis strongly suggests that the (hermaphrodite papaya) resulted from papaya domestication by the Maya or other indigenous groups.\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd To read about the Mesoamerican calendar, see "<a href="http://www.archaeology.org/issues/44-1211/features/386-maya-long-count-calendar">The Maya Sense of Time</a>."&nbsp;</p></div></summary>   <content type="html"><div class="feed-description"><p><img class="caption" style="margin-right: 15px; float: left;" title="(Rishi Aryal)" src="images/News/1503/Maya-papaya-domestication.JPG" alt="" width="298" height="269" />CHAMPAIGN, ILLINOIS\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdA genetic study of the sex chromosomes of the papaya plant suggests that the hermaphrodite version of the plant, which produces the fruit desired by growers, was first cultivated some 4,000 years ago by the Maya. Saraceni</name>    <email>saraceni@verizon.net</email>   </author>   <summary type="html"><div class="feed-description"><p><img class="caption" style="margin-right: 15px; float: left;" title=" " src="images/News/1503/Teotihucan-Collapse-Study.jpg" alt="Teotihucan-Collapse-Study" longdesc="(Wernervp/Wikimedia Commons)" width="355" height="186" />MEXICO CITY, MEXICO\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdLina Manzanilla of the Universidad Nacional Aut\ufffd\ufffdnoma de M\ufffd\ufffdxico thinks that Teotihuacan may have collapsed because of internal strife among its inhabitants. She says that volcanic eruptions in the first and fourth centuries forced people to move from the southern basin to the outskirts of Teotihuacan, where their skeletons, identified by activity markers, nutritional patterns, isotopes, and DNA analysis, have been found. According to <a href="http://phys.org/news/2015-03-anthropologist-explanation-collapse-ancient-city.html" target="_blank"><em>Phys.org</em></a>, Manzanilla says these immigrants were employed by businessmen and that their presence bolstered the economy. But eventually, tension with the government and rivalries between neighborhoods increased until an angry mob burned down the city\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds administration and ritual buildings and destroyed the city\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds sculptures. To read about a recent study comparing Teotihuacan and other ancient Mexican cities to modern urban centers, see "<a href="http://www.archaeology.org/issues/132-1405/trenches/1969-teotihuacan-ancient-and-modern-urban-growth">Big Data, Big Cities</a>."</p></div></summary>   <content type="html"><div class="feed-description"><p><img class="caption" style="margin-right: 15px; float: left;" title=" " src="images/News/1503/Teotihucan-Collapse-Study.jpg" alt="Teotihucan-Collapse-Study" longdesc="(Wernervp/Wikimedia Commons)" width="355" height="186" />MEXICO CITY, MEXICO\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdLina Manzanilla of the Universidad Nacional Aut\ufffd\ufffdnoma de M\ufffd\ufffdxico thinks that Teotihuacan may have collapsed because of internal strife among its inhabitants. Saraceni</name>    <email>saraceni@verizon.net</email>   </author>   <summary type="html"><div class="feed-description"><p><img class="caption" style="margin-right: 15px; float: left;" title="(Civil Protection of Friuli Venezia Giulia)" src="images/News/1503/first-Roman-fort.jpg" alt="" width="300" height="426" />TRIESTE, ITALY\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd<a href="http://phys.org/news/2015-03-oldest-roman-fort-trieste-italy.html" target="_blank"><em>Phys.org</em></a> reports that images created using information collected by Lidar technology revealed a Roman fort near Trieste, Italy, that has been dated to 178 B.C. The fort, called San Rocco, is said to be several decades older than any other Roman fort ever found. Two smaller forts have been discovered on either side of it. The fort may have been constructed during the second Istrian War, and could provide clues to the early days of the Roman army. The excavation of artifacts such as hobnails for military boots indicate the site was occupied until the mid-first century B.C. To read about a similar discovery in Germany, see "<a href="http://www.archaeology.org/issues/61-1301/features/269-top-10-2012-caesar-roman-military-camp">Caesar's Gallic Outpost</a>."&nbsp;</p></div></summary>   <content type="html"><div class="feed-description"><p><img class="caption" style="margin-right: 15px; float: left;" title="(Civil Protection of Friuli Venezia Giulia)" src="images/News/1503/first-Roman-fort.jpg" alt="" width="300" height="426" />TRIESTE, ITALY\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd<a href="http://phys.org/news/2015-03-oldest-roman-fort-trieste-italy.html" target="_blank"><em>Phys.org</em></a> reports that images created using information collected by Lidar technology revealed a Roman fort near Trieste, Italy, that has been dated to 178 B.C. Saraceni</name>    <email>saraceni@verizon.net</email>   </author>   <summary type="html"><div class="feed-description"><p><img class="caption" style="margin-right: 15px; float: left;" title="(The Swedish History Museum)" src="images/News/1503/Viking-Islamic-Ring.jpg" alt="Viking-Islamic-Ring" width="355" height="190" />STOCKHOLM, SWEDEN\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdThe recent examination of a ring excavated from a ninth-century grave in the Viking trading center of Birka, Sweden, more than 100 years ago suggests that Vikings had contact with Islamic civilization. The silver ring is adorned with a violet-colored piece of glass (long thought to have been an amethyst) engraved with an inscription that reads \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdTo Allah\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd or \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdFor Allah\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd in Arabic. A scanning electron microscope revealed little sign of wear on the ring, indicating that it had few owners before it was buried in the grave of a Viking woman. Ancient texts mention contact between Scandinavians and members of Islamic civilization, but such archaeological evidence is rare. \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdBeing the only ring with an Arabic inscription found at a Scandinavian archaeological site, it is a unique object among Swedish Viking Age material,\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd the scientists, led by biophysicist Sebastian W\ufffd\ufffdrml\ufffd\ufffdnder of Stockholm University, wrote in the journal <em>Scanning</em>, reported by <a href="https://www.sciencenews.org/article/ring-brings-ancient-viking-islamic-civilizations-closer-together" target="_blank"><em>Science News</em></a>. To read more in-depth about the archaeology of Vikings, see "<a href="http://www.archaeology.org/issues/168-1503/features/2969-ireland-dublin-early-viking-prescence">The Vikings in Ireland</a>."</p></div></summary>   <content type="html"><div class="feed-description"><p><img class="caption" style="margin-right: 15px; float: left;" title="(The Swedish History Museum)" src="images/News/1503/Viking-Islamic-Ring.jpg" alt="Viking-Islamic-Ring" width="355" height="190" />STOCKHOLM, SWEDEN\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdThe recent examination of a ring excavated from a ninth-century grave in the Viking trading center of Birka, Sweden, more than 100 years ago suggests that Vikings had contact with Islamic civilization. Saraceni</name>    <email>saraceni@verizon.net</email>   </author>   <summary type="html"><div class="feed-description"><p><img class="caption" style="margin-right: 15px; float: left;" title="(Michael S. Helfenbein)" src="images/News/1503/Malaria-Parasite-Study-Bones.JPG" alt="Malaria-Parasite-Study-Bones" width="355" height="207" />NEW HAVEN, CONNECTICUT\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdScientists from <a href="http://news.yale.edu/2015/03/17/creating-malaria-test-ancient-human-remains" target="_blank">Yale University</a> have established a diagnostic, human skeletal profile for malaria, a disease transmitted by mosquitoes. Graduate student Jamie Inwood and her colleagues developed a technique to identify the polymer hemozoin, which is produced by the parasite that causes malaria, using archaeological bone samples from a site dating to A.D. 550 in Teverina, Italy. \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdResearchers from the University of Arizona had found burial practices that were throwbacks to pagan rituals. It was suspected there must have been an epidemic in the community that caused fever or fits,\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Inwood said in a press release. The black, crystalline hemozoin clumps can be seen in bone marrow with x-ray defraction. Inwood is now collecting data on malaria from archaeological sites in West Africa. \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdThe data set we build with this will be revolutionary for establishing the epidemiological curve for malaria in ancient societies.
